comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Katherine Drexel Dahlgren (b. 1894) was arrested for "speeding her automobile ninety miles an hour on the main street [of Stockbridge MA] and for operating the racer in a reckless manner," in July 1915. She married Richard Smith Emmet in January 1917; in July 1918, she and her sister Ulrica both gave birth to daughters in the same hour, at their mother's summer house in Ridgefield CT. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10F15FD395D16738... query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40817FD345C10738... One of her grandfathers: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_A._Dahlgren Her other grandfather: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_William_Drexel

comment._content: I wonder how the constable clocked her speed...

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This January, 1917 NYT photo supplement, at lower left, shows KDD and her bridesmaids: memory.loc.gov/service/sgp/sgpnyt/1917/191701/19170128/00... A picture in a news item announcing her engagement from September, 1916 shows her dancing on skates with her fiance and tells more of her racing exploits: "DARING SOCIETY AUTOMOBILIST TO WED DANCING PARTNER . New York, Sept 30. Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren has announced the en - gagement of her daughter . Miss Katherine Drexel Dahlgren, one of t h e most daring automobilists among the young women of society, to Richard Smith Emmet of this city. The announcement was made by Mrs Dahlgren at Fairfield, Conn., where she and her children passed t he sum - mer and will remain through the autumn . Miss Dahlgren startled summer residents of the Berkshire Hills about Lenox , Mass., a year ago by driving a 120 horsepower Mercer automobile at racing speed through the highways. She was fined $25 for this and was admonished for treating other local automobile regulations lightly. Later she offered to race George E. Turnure, Jr., on a motorcycle at Berkshire Fair Grounds. In society she has been active in Lenox and in this city, where she has appeared in various entertainments of the Junior League." fultonhistory.com/newspaper%2010/Kingston%20NY%20Daily%20...

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thanks artolog and pennylrichardsca for the information about this interesting woman.  We will add more details to the description when we update.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: An account of the summer happenings among society at Lenox, Mass. in the New York Sun in the summer of 1915 has a very similar picture of Ms. Dahlgren in her car in what could be the same spot, but taken from the other side of the car. An accompanying article mentions that her race car was 120 horsepower, and she successfully defended herself from a charge that the car was too noisy by submitting that it was designed as an explosive race car, and that she would get it modified to make it more quiet. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%209/New%20York%20NY%20Sun/New... And in 1917, they were still talking about her: "In August of the same year she accepted a challenge to race her car against a motorcycle ridden by George E. Turnure, Jr. The highway authorities in the Hills were determined the race should not take place. Miss Dahlgren said:— "I simply couldn't take a dare from Mr. Turnure, particularly as I have driven my little yellow roadster at better than sixty miles an hour many times. If It is safe for a man to run a motorcycle at a faster clip than that, a girl ought to be able to go him one better with a powerful engine and four wheels. Mamma doesn't want me to take any risks, but dear mamma doesn't know that it is perfectly safe to drive a car fast when you know the roads perfectly. "All the village constables for miles around are watching us to prevent the race, but It will be over before they get through shining up their badges." New York Evening Telegram, Jan. 8, 1917 fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%206/New%20York%20NY%20Evenin...
